Key Arguments: The bill is based on the misconception that it is possible to objectively separate correct information from misinformation.
History shows that what is considered correct information can change over time.
The concept of information causing harm is illogical and unbounded.
The legislation represents an increase in government regulation and bureaucracy.
The bill could lead to an Orwellian scenario where a regulatory authority decides what is true or false.
The legislation threatens freedom of speech and could lead to more intolerance.
Notable Quotes: The belief that some regulatory authority will be able to discern what is correct, non-misleading information from what is not, can only lead to the realization of the Orwellian nightmare clearly foretold in the novel, '1984'.
The result of this legislation will be to give faceless people the indiscriminate power to decide what is 'good' information and what is 'bad' information.
A free and open society depends on the free exchange of ideas [including cranky ones as presently perceived].
